awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:   Understanding the Climate Mechanisms Associated with Past Drought and Vegetation Change.
awd_abstract_narration:
NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION
GEOGRAPHY SPATIAL SCIENCES (GSS) PROGRAM

ABSTRACT

This doctoral dissertation research project will use the modern climate analog technique to investigate the synoptic and dynamic climate processes associated with drought in the western U.S. and the possible responses of ecosystems to past megadroughts.  The doctoral student will provide new insights into how vegetative responses to past hydroclimate variability and disturbances can help protect and mitigate ecological communities against future environmental change.  An understanding of the climate processes associated with modern drought will provide deeper insights into past drought variability and the mechanisms that caused megadroughts evident in paleoecological records.  The student will work closely with local communities and government agencies by providing useful knowledge to resource managers regarding past hydroclimate variability and impacts to valuable natural resources.  In addition, the new insights into biodiversity dynamics associated with past megadroughts will inform policy-related discussions regarding ecological sustainability and land-management issues.  Results from this research would be useful for a broad range of uses, including species range modeling, predicting future ecosystem migration patterns in response to future climate change, and fire management in certain ecosystems.  As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

Understanding the range of natural variability related to past drought and wet periods is important for providing context to water resource managers for future water planning.  The doctoral student whose dissertation research will be supported by this award will use modern climate data during past dry and wet events as analogs for the events seen in the sedimentary record.  The project will focus on two core questions:  (1) What were the prevailing seasonal atmospheric circulation patterns and surface conditions over western North America during the megadrought centered around 4,200 years BP?  (2) What were the prevailing seasonal atmospheric circulation patterns over western North America during the wet event that followed the megadrought?  In order to identify possible synoptic and dynamic patterns that may have caused these two events in the western U.S., the student will apply a modern climate analog technique, which is a conceptual model that uses modern extremes as analogs of past events.  To accomplish this, a composite of anomaly values for selected modern climate analog case years will be mapped and analyzed for their spatiotemporal variability of surface and atmospheric conditions.

por.por_cntn:
The 20th century witnessed several devastating droughts which resulted in severe economic, societal and environmental hardships. However paleoclimatic records from lake sediments and tree rings suggest that droughts prior to the 20th century were more severe and of longer duration than those that occurred during the 20th century. Such ‘megadroughts’ are recorded by proxy evidence preserved in lake sediments (e.g. via pollen and charcoal) as an ecological response (e.g. a change in vegetation), however proxy evidence fail to record climatic mechanisms that caused such extreme events. For example, recent research identified a unique change in vegetation composition in southeastern Wyoming ~4000 years ago, from a pine dominated forest to a mixed-forest with pine and quaking aspen. Proxy evidence revealed a severe and long-lasting drought ~4200 year ago yet proxy evidence failed to record the climate processes responsible for this particular megadrought. By analyzing modern climate analogues of drought, this research sought to investigate potential climatic mechanisms responsible for the drought ~4200 years ago and the subsequent change in vegetation composition at Long Lake, southeastern Wyoming. The main results of this project are: (1) southeastern Wyoming drought is significantly influenced by western Great Plains climate anomalies, and (2) similar atmospheric processes that occurred during the drought of 2002 and 2012 (i.e. anomalous high-pressure ridges positioned over the Great Plains region) may have occurred during the drought 4200 years ago. In lieu of climate simulations for the 4.2 ka event (i.e. the drought 4200 years ago), modern climate analogues provide clues as to potential climate mechanisms responsible for the drought that plagued the western Great Plains/southeastern Wyoming region approximately 4200 years ago.

This doctoral dissertation improvement grant achieved several education goals, including training of a first-generation college female graduate student. She (the CoPI) broadened her skill set to include synoptic and dynamic climatology training which augments her already established training in paleoecology. She presented the results of this DDRI grant at several national conferences and one international workshop, one webinar to a federal agency (which is open-access), as well as published the results in two peer-reviewed journals (one of them being open-access). In addition, she successfully defended her Ph.D. dissertation and has been working as a post-doctoral researcher.
